THE BITESIZE:SIMILAR GAMEPLAY TO: Killing Floor, other wave survival shooters.WHAT TO EXPECT: Four modes inc. survival coop, pvp and variants.  Hell/Demonic themes.  Shooter & melee combat.  Simple dynamics:  Kill. Survive. Stop 'Hell' from raging enemies.  Decent graphics starting to show their age.  Underrated gameplay.  ACHIEVEMENTS: FAIRLY EASY but a few are grindy. STATUS: ABOUT TO BE REVIVED. New DLC planned. Almost dead community.WHEN TO BUY:  ON SALE.More info below....THE LOWDOWN:The Haunted: Hells Reach is a third-person, wave/survival shooter set in demonic themed reality set in a western-style backdrop.  The objective is simple: join the side of good (or evil.) Shoot, punch, kick and blast numerous demonic minions across five or so waves (depending on the mode) Defeat the great hulking demon Adadon in the final battle.  Overall the game possesses a Painkiller aesthetic with a Killing Floor feel.KEY FEATURES: Solo, coop or pvp modes. Six or so large maps of different locations. Several game modes inc: Inferno (wave survival) and Survival (endless), Battle (pvp). Four unique, well-voiced characters. Three core weapons (handguns, shotguns, rifles) with six upgraded models. Numerous special weapons and grenade types littered around levels. Collect soulstones in quick-time to stop enemies entering a rage mode.   Various demonic minion types with their own abilities, attacks and deadly rage mode.THE GOOD:+ V. good and stable netcode with listen server mode.+ Nice designed and streamlined gameplay makes for a very fun game.+ Weapon classes maybe limited to three but the upgrades are very different and satifying to use.  Upgrading is so well ingraved in the action that choosing which weapons to upgrade is done on the fly.+ Very well conceived achievements.  Only one grinding achievement and a two tricky but easy to get achievements.  Overall very satisfying to unlock for achievement unhunters/completionists.+ Good range of difficulty levels from: Beginner to Nightmare, provides an excellent learning curve.THE BAD:- Enemies are quite fast and will be upon you on harder levels before you can react.  Giving the impression of getting overwhelmed quickly.  Put me off playing at first.- Spawn frequency doesnt seem to be that well geared towards difficulty- Dead community.  Although there are a very few die hards from time to time you will struggle to get anyone to join your game or find one on going.  Which is a real shame!- The games heavy demonic theme may put you off if thats not your cup-of-tea.- Doesnt scale to well with more players.AND THE ORDINARY:* A really nice selection of game modes including: wave survival, versus (pvp) and a mix of both allow for some change-up when you feel the need.* Well-rounded characters with good one-liners and _ voice-overs.* While the graphics maybe dated by todays standard they held up very well and immerse players in the setting.* The use of soulstones to keep players on their toes is a nice touch.  Fail to get these before time runs out and the pace, franticness increases.  Includes some nice environmental changes to penalise the player some more.* An average soundtrack which switches from one track to a second when gameplay changes normal pace to * Its a port with console style gameplay moves and controls.  But its a decent one and it works well on PC at all levels.VERDICT:Dropped like a hot potato when first played, I really did not take to Haunted: Hells Reach.  I found the game slow, difficult and frustating.  Nothing made sense.  After a few years gathering dust I decided to give this another try.  Suffice to say I was really glad I did!By starting on easier difficulty and learning the game's mechanics, I really enjoyed my experience during this second pass.  Graphics may become dated but for the time being they hold their own.  Game mechanics are concise and robust, making for fluid gameplay.  Sure its very repetitive and at times five waves seem a little long but despite these its alot of fun.  The combination of destroying soulstones within the time limit and weapon upgrading work well keeping you invested in playing. The range of enemies require some tactics especially when they enter rage mode, increasing the challenge to a satisfying level.  Probably one of the highlights are the range of characters and the very apt one-liners they spit out as you slaughter the devils minions!Potential downsides are the slightly clunky controls and 'on-top of you' enemy spawning which together, can cause premature death!  The Haunted plays fine in solo but is much better fun with other players.  PvP where players can choose to play on the side of good or control the evil minions could actually have been very good!  Its just a shame that there is no community to speak of anymore.  Overall its actually far better than I had originally thought.  If youre looking for an ultimate challenge from a coop wave survival shooter, you cant get much harder than on Nightmare.   Despite its age its a very underrated title.  One I would recommended mostly on a decent sale.  Be aware that now that its under new ownership the brand looks about to be re-vitalized.   At least with a new dlc.

												The Haunted Hells Reach is a third person action horror cooperative game. The goal is to liberate cursed places and survive the assault from the minions of Hell.Four game modes are offered: Survival, Battle, Demonizer and Inferno. Each mode can be played on any of The Haunted’s eight maps. Survival simply makes you keep fighting until you die, which is not a particularly engaging objective, while Battle and Demonizer are The Haunted’s efforts at player-versus-player modes. In Inferno, which is the best mode of the game, four players must survive four waves of enemies that increase in number and power over time before fighting Abaddon, a huge boss monster in a separate Hell level.  The player is equiped with a handgun, shotgun, machine gun and knife. You will unlock upgrades to these as you kill.The game has also a deep melee system that gives the player an easy way out when surrounded by undead.Unfortunately, networking issues can make locating or connecting to someone’s game difficult. The biggest problem of The Haunted Hells Reach is that joining a game forces you to wait until the next wave of enemies, which can sometimes be 10+ minutes until you can finally play.in my opinion, if you are seeking a new, unique team-based game to play with some friends, The Haunted Hells Reach is a worthy choice.Sounds 6/10Graphics 6/10Gameplay 7/10Atmosphere 7/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

The community says "Normal" is an untested difficulty...and it has +2 more difficulties above normal.  I barely beat normal.The combat mechanics are fantastic.  It's damn near cartoony over-the-top holywood, but, the mechanics play out very well.  Melee and unarmed combos mix up well with ranged attacks and level up your inventory.  You can prioritize which weapons to upgrade.Certain monsters are immune to ranged when enraged (when u fail to finish them off during their stun period) and thus hafta be taken care of in close combat.  If you have someone prioritizing close combat/melee then they can go in and assassinate raged enemies before it gets out of hand.When a player dies a totem spawns with player's soul that must be touched to respawn them;  However, a monster can steal the soul and run away, getting lost in horde, forcing co-op team to risk going after it.  Health totems spawn and hafta be dealt with in same way.  Really cool mechanic and clutch for such a steep difficulty curve.  It's very satisfying getting combos off as each enemy kill regens ur health (but less and less on higher difficulties).They made this game long time ago for a contest, then refined it and fixed the bugs.  It was worth the effort, very unique co-op survival game.  I'm buying copies for lan and online parties since its fun and easy to get into but hard to master.

												This is your generic type of humans versus waves of zombies/monsters type scenario. It isn't very special, but it is definitely something good to come back to every once in awhile. This is a third person shooter and it has a nice variety of weapons. You can upgrade your weapon for it to level up to the next tier. The tier system is, however, opinionated on which is better or worse. Regardless, it's a nice take  on a weapon system. The monsters are demons, which has a variety of types out there. you'll have the generic not zombie but still cannon fodder like a zombie type monster, then you got the generic winged demon. You got the big orc like guys and then you got these weird tiny bug like things. The diversity is good. There is a type of giant demon that eventually becomes immune to gun damage, whom encourages melee combat since that's the only way to kill it. Speaking of melee combat, you have not just the primary weapons or sidearms, but also a melee weapon with different melee attacks like kicking. You probably will not use them all a whole lot, but it's still a worthy try in variety that I wish more games would have. (I miss kicking in games greatly)When you finish the waves, you eventually fight the final boss. The final boss feels cheap at first, but it's possible with practice. It basically is a giant ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of a demon that walks around in lava, throwing lava♥♥♥♥♥♥at you, all the meanwhile the immune to gun damage guys spawn all over the place trying to attack you while bursts of lava comes out of the ground. It is a climatic ending and it was climatic at first, but it gets old after awhile... like the game itself.As I have said before, the game is something you'll wanna come back to every once in awhile, especially with friends. Its graphics are good and so is the lighting, not amazing but good enough, the sound is what you'd want, the characters are kinda over the top in personality like a bad horror movie- which is a good thing - and their design is nice. There is a variety of game modes, one of which you can play in a strategy game like perspective and spawn enemies or even choose to play as the enemy yourself. It isn't that fun in my opinion to be the bad guys because you'll die so quickly and you have a spawn timer on when you can spawn more enemies, which might be good for balance and fairness for the humans but it makes you feel bored just sitting there pressing the button over and over again... even cookie clicker is more fun than that. There is a survival mode as well, it's as you'd expect and it's fun as well.Overall, the game is good. I wouldn't buy it full price, I would consider buying it on sale for around $5. Apparently the developers are hinting something is afoot with the title. We'll see what that means and I'll edit my review accordingly if it any way changes my overall opinion. For now, this is a good bargin title, don't buy it at full price.Pros:A good enough variety in enemies and weaponsLighting and atmosphere is niceGameplay is fun for beginners and veterans alikeA healthy amount of gamemodesCons:Not many hours should be expected to be put in this right away, but it is something you could launch for years to come in every five or so months. This game will get stale pretty quick.The combat seems unbalanced, you could spam some moves and do just fineOverall, I give it a score of a 6ish/10. For people that are unfamiliar with rating scales, 6 isn't bad.

												This game has likely flown under the radar of practically everyone here on Steam, and that is somewhat of a shame.The Haunted Hells Reach is a horde based wave shooter in which you play as four stereotypical badasses with no difference other than how corny their lines in combat are. You face wave after wave of the undead as you fight to survive with an ugradable arsenal of Knife, Shotgun, Machine Gun, and pistol. Each weapon has it's own upgrade tree, with the knife becoming a chainsaw at somepoint whilst your pistol becomes two revolvers. Along with this, you can pick up several other exotic weapons like a bow with explosives or a rocket launcher. You can also find explosives such as grenades and mines as well.The online community at this point is dead in the water for this game, a shame since it is best enjoyed online. However physical copies of the game exist and for as little as a dollar, it's utterly worth it in my opinion. The more players, the more challenging the game becomes. And there is even a mode in which you can play as the demons in an effort to murder your friends.The graphics are decent enough, servicable if you will, the animations aren't awful, and the textures for the environments are solid enough, though you don't have much time to admire because enemies come from everywhere.Luckily, enemies rarely become all aggressive, which makes the game a hell (HA!) of a lot better. If you have some friends then this game will be an enjoyable time of 8/10.However if horde based games aren't your thing then perhaps Doom might be more your speed.

												This is definitely a unknown and severely underestimated gem.It's nothing terribly fance. Just a very action-packed, quick and arcade-y 'kill everything before it kills you' type arena survival shooter. The gameplay itself consist of a mix of gunplay and melee action, combined with tons of explosives (and explosions) and a life-saving dodge mechanic.If you like L4D or Killing Floor, but feel that both those games have slow player characters and are not action-heavy enough, give Haunted a try.Be warned though, Haunted is definitely on a higher difficulty level then any of the two compared games. Whilst on the lowest of the 5 difficulty grades you might easily survive the first of the four waves, the later ones will usually kill you on your first attempt, with suicidal green-goo spitting maniacs, walking volcanos and Freddy-style nightmare warriors. And if we start about the highest difficulty level... boy... imagine L4D expert realism with 80% of all infected being special infected :PThe pros of Haunted are clear: Solid gameplay, tons of action and reflex-based thinking, mixed with a solid note of badassery.However, I must be fair and mention it's downsides too: There is no character progression, any weapon upgrades you gather in a match are reverted at the end of a level. As well, there's literally no online playerbase for this game. This really isn't a bad thing and I enjoy it a lot in singleplayer, but if you are the coop only type of person, you may want to bring some friends. Lastly, it lacks diversity and is one of those games you just cant play 8 hours in a row or you will grow bored.Overall, Haunted is one of my longest-active games, simply because it's always fun to relax with techno/speedcore battle music via winampw hilst playing a round or two on Nightmare difficulty. Whenever I feel like blowing faces up, I just grab winamp, Haunted, and splode away.Rating: 8/10

												This game has been quite the mix of feelings for me. On the one hand it's good for some laughs, the weapons get progressivly more awesome the more you upgrade them and the Demonizer gamemode is pretty cool when you want to just be a giant jerk and summon minions on your former teammates should you die or kill yourself (much like I do just to summon junk). On the other hand, the laughs start to fade after about 15 minutes, it's very repetitive and the game knows exactly when and where to become an absolutly evil ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ about everything.This game heavily focuses on teamwork (Teamwork being the key word) and at times, almost demands you to play with others as opposed with playing solo which would be ok if it wasn't for the fact that:1. playing on your own is both boring and tedious and 2. there's no one to help you whatsoever should things go wrong and odds are, they probably will. That's not to say that playing solo is entirely bad. If that's your thing, you go right ahead and do it, but be prepared for a letdown the further in you go. That being said however, this game actually gets fun the more friends you play it with (God knows how many times I've laughed with each Character's catchphrases like a madman since I like each of them and their dialogs) and allows you to keep playing for longer without that droning feeling. Unfortunatly, that requires 4 seperate friends with 4 seperate copies who may not even want to get this in the first place, so shelling up for a 4-Pack to enjoy this game starts feeling like less of a choice and more of a demand.As for Characters, I do like them all as I've said before. Each one comes with "kill phrases" that they blurt out everytime they gib a demon or pick up something very deadly to use.All in all, for the current price it is (Note: this was written at the time the price dropped by 75% in the Autumn 2013 sales), it's good for some laughs, some fun and messing around in general. For the full price? I'm sorry but that's asking for too much for what this is.Buy this only if you really want it and it's on offer, simply put.

Sticking together & constantly moving is the key to winning here. Seperating from your team is basically suicide in the later stages when the waves have more unit variety & more aggressive enemies. There's 12 weapons and 6 types of explosives. Each time you kill an enemy with a weapon that weapon gains experience. Each weapon can be upgraded five times and for each time you upgrade it, it changes. On Forsaken Canyon there's a thunderstorm for example. It obstructs your sight and random thunderbolts hit the ground. If you get hit you get stunned for a short time.
